channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: How Russia Sanctions Could Affect India
item.description: U.S. and EU penalties on Russian oil companies raise the stakes for New Delhi’s trade talks with Washington.

item.title: South Korea Courts Trump During Visit
item.description: East Asian countries are using a tried-and-true method to woo the U.S. president and secure better trade deals.

item.title: India’s IPO boom is good news for its economy
item.description: Stockmarkets appear to be fuelling investment

item.title: The U.S. Government’s Repair Bills Are Coming Due
item.description: Decades of accumulated technical debt have hollowed out state capacity.

item.title: Tanzania’s Unfree Election
item.description: The country heads to the polls in an increasingly authoritarian political environment.

item.title: ‘Putin Doesn’t Want Peace’
item.description: Estonia’s president on Russia, Ukraine, NATO, drones, and Trump.

item.title: The U.S. Is Withdrawing Some Troops From Eastern Europe
item.description: Top congressional Republicans expressed concern over the lack of consultation.

item.title: A letter to investors from the White House Opportunities Fund
item.description: How the shift to state capitalism is panning out for America LLC

item.title: Scientists may have found a panacea for snake bites
item.description: A broad-spectrum antivenom could save thousands of lives a year

item.title: Europe’s defence firms are flying. Now for the hard part
item.description: Valuations have surged since Donald Trump’s return. Are investors heading for disappointment?

item.title: A bloody police raid in Rio was the deadliest in Brazil’s history
item.description: Brazil’s conservatives are keener on such raids than its left-wing government

item.title: America is upgrading GPS to catch up with rivals
item.description: The system should soon become harder to jam or fool

item.title: Javier Milei’s chance to transform Argentina and teach the world
item.description: Lessons in public finance from the original sinner

item.title: Milei’s Midterm Miracle
item.description: Did Argentine voters endorse their president’s economic overhaul—or cow to Trump’s threats?

item.title: Tear gas and Halloween costumes in America’s third largest city
item.description: Operation Midway Blitz in Chicago is out of hand

item.title: Profiles in Weakness at the Trump-Xi Meeting
item.description: While most people regard the Sino-American rivalry as a new cold war between two world-bestriding giants, the truth is that both countries are tightly constrained. Presidents Donald Trump and Xi Jinping each sense the other side's vulnerabilities, which means they cannot hide their own.

item.title: The Trump-Xi Summits, Then and Now: Trade, Taiwan, and Russia
item.description: Six years after their last meeting, the agenda looks the same – but the needle has moved on each of the three top issues.

item.title: Wargaming China’s Dominance in Rare Earths and Critical Minerals
item.description: Insights from Finley Grimble.

item.title: Why Putin’s Energy Weapon Failed
item.description: New measures from the United States and European Union confirm why Russian energy exports were always a double-edged sword.

item.title: The Remaking of the Indian Army Since Operation Sindoor
item.description: India has been rapidly restructuring its military, taking advantage of the fact that it is still technically on a war footing.

item.title: China’s Development Strategy in the 15th Five-Year Plan Era
item.description: The goals of the 15th Five-Year Plan reflect significant shifts compared to its predecessor.

item.title: Takaichi’s Ambitious Economic and Security Agenda for Japan
item.description: In her first policy speech, Japan’s new prime minister made big promises that hinge on big spending.

item.title: Neglected Solutions to Our Biggest Problems
item.description: To rebuild the middle class, reduce global poverty, and address climate change simultaneously, we need to depart from established ways of thinking and consider new approaches. Fortunately, many of these approaches already exist at the local level, where they have proved themselves and need only to be recognized.

item.title: China’s Private Sector: Unseen and Unsung
item.description: Private enterprises power China's economy, but received no attention in the latest plenum communique.

item.title: India’s Farm Policies Behind Bad Air, Unhealthy Diet, Water Crisis
item.description: Law and policy measures that prioritize sustainable agriculture are needed to address India’s environmental challenges.

item.title: The Global Polytunity
item.description: Western leaders favor the language of “polycrisis” because it obscures the root cause of our current predicament: the industrial-colonial paradigm. Instead of focusing on fear, the world must study and tackle development challenges with a purposeful realism that draws on the creativity of a genuinely global community.

item.title: South Korea and US Presidents Talk Tariffs, Nuclear Subs at Summit
item.description: On the sidelines of the APEC Summit in Gyeongju, Presidents Lee Jae-myung and Donald Trump met again, two months after their first summit at the White House.

item.title: French Shipyard Proposes Partnering With India’s Mazagon Dock to Build Subs for Export
item.description: They pledged to cooperate in ‘joint export of submarines to a mutually friendly country,’ but have not named the client country so far.

item.title: Trump, Xi Attacks on Rights a Challenge for APEC Summit
item.description: At a summit dominated by two leaders who have demonstrated utter hostility to the international system, human rights law, and democratic principles, how should rights-respecting, democratic countries respond?

item.title: Trump’s Meeting With Xi Must Deliver Wins, Not Photo Ops
item.description: The question is not whether Trump can strike a deal, but what he is willing to surrender to claim one.

item.title: In Russia, Enemies Are Everywhere
item.description: Russians were promised a quick victory in Ukraine; instead, they have gotten a protracted and costly conflict reminiscent of the Afghan quagmire that contributed to the collapse of the Soviet Union. None of this is lost on President Vladimir Putin, who is ramping up prosecutions to eliminate potential rivals.

item.title: Courts Are Shaping the Future of Climate Action
item.description: In the absence of political will, the law has become a crucial driver of climate progress. Recent rulings make it clear that countries have binding legal duties to cut emissions, phase out fossil fuels, and finance adaptation efforts, laying the groundwork for stronger commitments at COP30.

item.title: Russia Aims to Freeze Ukraine Into Submission
item.description: Moscow is targeting Ukraine’s natural gas supply, right with winter just around the corner.

item.title: Is Trump Ruling Like a King?
item.description: When millions of protesters came out this month to say, “No Kings,” Donald Trump posted an AI-generated video of himself being crowned, only to insist, the next day, that he is not a king. But how he sees himself ultimately matters less than how Congress, the courts, the business community, and the electorate do.

item.title: ASEAN’s Mixed Feelings About U.S.-China Detente
item.description: What if China ends up with a better deal than Southeast Asia?

item.title: The Military-Narrational Complex
item.description: What stories do in an age of conflict.

item.title: Structure Trumps Agency in the U.S.-China Relationship
item.description: Why the competition is here to stay.

item.title: Pakistan’s Islamist Parties Pivot to Economic Populism
item.description: But to win the support of mainstream voters, they need to open themselves to accountability, without which their talk of fixing the economy rings hollow.

item.title: Can Trump and Xi Strike a Deal?
item.description: Both sides are sending positive signals ahead of a Thursday meeting, but a temporary truce may be more likely.
